objdescid.compdate: c. 1794-1806Bentley notes that the date is problematic, as "The Phoenix" is likely to have been written during Blake's closest association with his chief patron Thomas Butts, somewhere between 1794-1806 (Blake Books Supplement page 105).

objinfo.note: Bentley notes that the basic ink of the lettering is a somewhat odd rather pale blue, but the letters are touched up wth red (fading to a brownish orange), pale brown (fading to brownish green), with a little brownish purple (including the bottom right corner) (Blake Books Supplement page 105).
objinfo.framelines: straight lines at the right and bottom of the page; curling lines at the left. See Object Note for more information.

provenance.name: British Library
provenance.note: Given by Blake around 1794 to the dedicatee Elizabeth Butts, wife of Thomas Butts; passed by inheritance to Butts's daughter by her first marriage, Mary Anne North; passed down to North's grandson, Mr. Owen D. Long; deposited by Long in 1981; sold by Long to the British Museum Print Room in July 1985.

objnote.p: The poem is written within a frame consisting of mostly straight lines at the right and bottom, curling like a vine at the left. To the right of the title is a faint Blake-like flying figure, as in Thel pl. 2, with a flying bird to the right of the figure. There seems to be no significance in the colors added to the letters, except that it is often where the blue is faint. The manuscript appears to be designed to look like Blake's work in Illuminated Printing. (Bentley, Blake Books Supplement pages 105-6)

lg.l: I saw a Bird rise from the East
As a Bird rises from its Nest
With sweetest Songs I ever heard
It sang. I am Mrs Butts's Bird
And then I saw a Fairy gay
That with this beauteous Bird would play
From a golden cloud she came
She calldcalled the sweet Bird by its name
She call'dcalled it Phoenix! Heavens Dove!
She call'dcalled it all the names of Love
But the Bird flew fast away
Where little children sport & play
And they strok'dstroked it with their hands
All their cooe'scoos it understands
The Fairy to my bosom flew
Weeping tears of morning dew
I said: Thou foolish whimpringwhimpering thing
Is not that thy Fairy Ring
Where those Children sport & play
In Fairy fancies light & gay
Seem a Child & be a Child
And the Phoenix is beguildbeguiled
But if thou seem'st a Fairy thing
Then it flies on glancing Wing
William Blake
